trans-unit.source: A public suffix is one under which Internet users can directly register names. Some examples of public suffixes are .com, .co.uk and pvt.k12.wy.us. Accurately knowing the public suffix of a domain is useful when handling web browser cookies, highlighting the most important part of a domain name in a user interface or sorting URLs by web site.
trans-unit.target: A public suffix is one under which Internet users can directly register names. Some examples of public suffixes are .com, .co.uk and pvt.k12.wy.us. Accurately knowing the public suffix of a domain is useful when handling web browser cookies, highlighting the most important part of a domain name in a user interface or sorting URLs by web site.

trans-unit.source: This module allows you to get the public suffix of a domain name using the Public Suffix List from http://publicsuffix.org
trans-unit.target: This module allows you to get the public suffix of a domain name using the Public Suffix List from http://publicsuffix.org

trans-unit.source: This module ships with an out-dated copy of the Public Suffix List for compatibility with older versions. Use of this list is deprecated since it encouraged applications that never updated the Public Suffix List data. The built-in list will be removed in a future version.
trans-unit.target: This module ships with an out-dated copy of the Public Suffix List for compatibility with older versions. Use of this list is deprecated since it encouraged applications that never updated the Public Suffix List data. The built-in list will be removed in a future version.

trans-unit.source: part of an URL can contain strings that are not plain DNS domain names (IP addresses, Punycode-encoded names, name in combination with a port number or an username, etc.). It is up to the caller to ensure only domain names are passed to the get_public_suffix() method.
